vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/04e82af3-e6ca-4600-ba3b-9837fe476ba5">WORKING CONDITIONS</keyword>         <topcClas>General - Employment and labour</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The aims of the project were:<br> to develop knowledge and understanding of the changing role of trades unions in the workplace, as perceived by employees;<br> in particular, to establish the influence trade unions have on workplace governance, and how this may have changed over time, identifying factors associated with better and worse governance;<br> to produce policy interpretations of the main findings so as to inform the policy debate surrounding the 'Fairness at Work' White Paper and the new statutory procedures for union recognition.<br> The data are items relating to employment taken from the British Social Attitudes Surveys (BSA), 1983-1998, plus a number of derived variables. Care has been taken to produce variables that are consistent across the series. The original BSA datasets are all held at the UK Data Archive - see under GN:33168.</abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br> The data cover employment, trade union issues and membership, attitudes to work and management, income distribution and demographic details.<br> <br> Standard Measures<br> Includes Hope-Goldthorpe occupational classifications and a number of Likert scales - see BSA yearly documentation for further information.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd>1983-1998, excluding 1988 and 1982</timePrd>         <nation>Great Britain</nation>         <geogUnit>Standard Statistical Regions</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Adults</universe>         <universe>Respondents to the 1983-1998 BSA surveys, with the focus on employees.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Cross-sectional (one-time) study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>covers BSA surveys 1983-1998</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Social and Community Planning Research</dataCollector>         <sampProc>One-stage stratified or systematic random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>38141 (obtained)</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview; Self-completion</collMode>         <sources>           <dataSrc>The data originators are National Centre for Social Research (formerly SCPR), who are responsible for the BSA series.</dataSrc>         </sources>         <weight>No information recorded</weight>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. (1999) 'Are unions good for industrial relations?' IN R. Jowell et al (eds) <i>British Social Attitudes: the 16th report - who shares New Labour values?</i>, Aldershot: Ashgate.<br> <li>Bryson, A. (2001) <i>Union effects on workplace governance, 1983-1998</i>, draft PSI discussion paper.<br></relPubl>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
